title: Ezekiel Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 7.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:2, to whom did the Lord GOD speak about the end coming upon the land?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:2 states that the Lord GOD spoke to the land of Israel about the end coming upon it.

questions.question: What will the LORD send upon Israel according to Ezekiel 7:3?
questions.correctAnswer: His anger
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:3 indicates that God will send His anger upon Israel and judge them according to their ways.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7:4 says that God's eye will spare Israel and He will have pity on them.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:4 clearly states that God's eye shall not spare Israel and He will not have pity on them.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:5, what kind of evil is come?
questions.correctAnswer: An evil, an only evil
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:5 states 'An evil, an only evil, behold, is come.'

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7:7 say is near for those dwelling in the land?
questions.correctAnswer: The day of trouble
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:7 mentions that the day of trouble is near for those dwelling in the land.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:10, what hath blossomed and pride hath budded?
questions.correctAnswer: The rod
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:10 states 'the rod hath blossomed, pride hath budded.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 7:12: 'The time is come, the day draweth near: let not the ______ rejoice, nor the seller mourn.'
questions.correctAnswer: buyer
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:12 says 'let not the buyer rejoice, nor the seller mourn.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:15, what will happen to those in the field?
options: They shall die with the sword
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die with the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:15 states those in the field shall die with the sword.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7:16 describes the survivors as rejoicing on the mountains like doves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:16 describes survivors as mourning on the mountains like doves, not rejoicing.

questions.question: What shall cover the people, and what shall be upon their heads according to Ezekiel 7:18?
options: Horror shall cover them; baldness upon their heads
Joy shall cover them; crowns upon their heads
Peace shall cover them; wreaths upon their heads
Light shall cover them; glory upon their heads
questions.correctAnswer: Horror shall cover them; baldness upon their heads
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:18 states they shall be covered with horror and baldness shall be upon their heads.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7:19 says silver and gold will save the people on the day of the LORD's wrath.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 says silver and gold shall not deliver them in the day of the LORD's wrath.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:21, who will receive the land as spoil?
options: Strangers and the wicked of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers and the wicked of the earth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:21 states the land will be given into the hands of strangers and the wicked of the earth.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Ezekiel 7:23 for making a chain?
options: Because the land is full of bloody crimes and the city full of violence
Because of great joy and celebration
Because of the harvest and blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Because the land is full of bloody crimes and the city full of violence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:23 commands to make a chain because the land is full of bloody crimes and the city is full of violence.

questions.question: What will happen to the holy places according to Ezekiel 7:24?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be defiled
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:24 states the holy places shall be defiled.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ezekiel 7:25: 'Destruction cometh; and they shall seek ______, and there shall be none.'
questions.correctAnswer: peace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:25 says 'Destruction cometh; and they shall seek peace, and there shall be none.'

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about God's judgment. Based on Ezekiel 7, what biblical truth about God's justice and mercy would you share?
options: God will judge according to our ways and abominations without pity
God overlooks sins to show mercy
God's anger is temporary and soon forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge according to our ways and abominations without pity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:3-4, 7:8-9 explain that God will judge Israel according to their ways and abominations and will not have pity or spare them. This teaches that God's justice is sure and righteous.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 7 teach about humility in the face of pride and wickedness?
options: Pride will bud and blossom, leading to destruction
Humility is unnecessary in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Pride will bud and blossom, leading to destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:10-11 describe pride blossoming as a rod of wickedness, leading to no survivors. This warns believers to embrace humility rather than pride to avoid judgment.

questions.question: In a time of trial, how does Ezekiel 7 encourage believers to trust in God's sovereignty even when destruction seems near?
options: God's wrath is purposeful and reveals His lordship
Destruction is random and without meaning
Believers should rely on wealth for protection
God abandons His people in trials
questions.correctAnswer: God's wrath is purposeful and reveals His lordship
questions.explanation: Verses 7:4, 7:9, and 7:27 show that God's judgment is just and reveals that He is the LORD. This encourages believers to trust His sovereignty during hardships.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to trust in riches for security. What does Ezekiel 7 warn about relying on silver and gold in times of God's wrath?
options: Silver and gold cannot deliver in the day of wrath
Possessions are a sign of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold cannot deliver in the day of wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 teaches that silver and gold will not satisfy or save people during God's wrath, highlighting the futility of trusting in material wealth.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 7 instruct us about honesty and integrity in daily life amid widespread violence and crime?
options: The land is full of bloody crimes, so integrity is crucial to stand apart
Crime is unavoidable, so compromise is necessary
Integrity is irrelevant in times of turmoil
questions.correctAnswer: The land is full of bloody crimes, so integrity is crucial to stand apart
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:23 highlights the land's fullness of crimes and violence, implying believers must maintain honesty and integrity despite the prevailing corruption.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by continuous misfortunes and rumors. According to Ezekiel 7, what practical biblical advice can you offer about perseverance and seeking spiritual guidance?
options: Seek the vision of the prophet despite the loss of law and counsel
Ignore spiritual counsel and rely on rumors
Give up seeking guidance during hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Seek the vision of the prophet despite the loss of law and counsel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:26 encourages seeking prophetic vision even as law and counsel perish, teaching believers to persevere in seeking God’s guidance.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7 teaches that God's anger will not be poured out on the land of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:8 clearly states that God's fury and anger will be poured out on the land, confirming that His judgment is coming.

questions.question: True or False: In Ezekiel 7, the day of trouble is described as being near and unavoidable for those dwelling in the land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:7 confirms that the day of trouble is near and cannot be escaped, emphasizing the certainty of coming judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 7, those who escape the destruction will be like ______ on the mountains, mourning for their iniquity.
questions.correctAnswer: doves of the valleys
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:16 uses the simile of doves on the mountains to describe the mournful survivors reflecting on their sins.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 7 emphasize the importance of repentance and turning from abominations?
options: God will recompense all abominations and they will be in the midst
Abominations are overlooked if one prays
Repentance is optional to avoid judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God will recompense all abominations and they will be in the midst
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:3-4 indicates God's judgment includes recompense for abominations in the midst of the people, urging repentance to avoid wrath.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7 teach about the role of prayer and readiness in the face of coming judgment?
options: The trumpet is blown to make all ready, but none go to battle because of God's wrath
Readiness is unnecessary when God is angry
questions.correctAnswer: The trumpet is blown to make all ready, but none go to battle because of God's wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:14 explains that although the trumpet sounds to prepare, none go to battle due to God's wrath, highlighting the need for spiritual readiness and prayer.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7, how should believers view the futility of trusting in human strength and worldly power?
options: The pomp of the strong will cease and holy places will be defiled
Strong leaders will protect the people
questions.correctAnswer: The pomp of the strong will cease and holy places will be defiled
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:24 teaches that God's judgment will end worldly pomp and defile holy places, warning believers not to trust in human power.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with shame and guilt over sin. What does Ezekiel 7 say about the natural response to realizing one's iniquity?
options: They will mourn, gird with sackcloth, and have shame upon their faces
They will feel pride and defiance
They will be joyful despite sin
questions.correctAnswer: They will mourn, gird with sackcloth, and have shame upon their faces
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:18 describes how the people will respond to judgment with mourning, sackcloth, and shame, showing the appropriate humble response to sin.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 7 inform us about the consequences of turning away from God's law in leadership and counsel?
options: The law will perish from the priest and counsel from the ancients
Law and counsel will strengthen during trials
questions.correctAnswer: The law will perish from the priest and counsel from the ancients
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:26 warns that during judgment, the law will perish from priests and counsel from elders, showing the collapse of spiritual leadership when people turn away from God.

questions.question: What biblical principle concerning generosity and stewardship can be drawn from Ezekiel 7's message about silver and gold?
options: Material wealth cannot replace righteousness or save from God's wrath
Accumulating wealth is the key to God's favor
Wealth is always a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Material wealth cannot replace righteousness or save from God's wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 teaches that silver and gold will not save people in the day of wrath, emphasizing the need for righteous living over material trust.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 7.

questions.question: What phrase in Ezekiel 7 indicates the certainty and imminence of judgment upon Israel?
options: An end, the end is come
The valley of dry bones shall live
A new covenant I will make
questions.correctAnswer: An end, the end is come
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:2 states, 'An end, the end is come upon the four corners of the land,' underscoring the certainty and imminence of divine judgment on Israel.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 7, what does God say He will recompense upon the people of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: All thine abominations
questions.explanation: The text in Ezekiel 7:3 indicates that God will judge Israel according to their ways and recompense all their abominations, showing divine justice for their sins.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 7:10 with the phrase 'the rod hath blossomed, pride hath budded'?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The phrase in Ezekiel 7:10 uses metaphorical language to symbolize the growth of pride and impending judgment, common in prophetic literature.

questions.question: What calamities are described as coming upon the people both inside and outside the city in Ezekiel 7?
options: Sword outside, pestilence and famine inside
questions.correctAnswer: Sword outside, pestilence and famine inside
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:15 clearly states that the sword will be outside, and pestilence and famine will be inside the city, depicting a comprehensive disaster.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7:19, why will silver and gold not deliver the people in the day of the LORD's wrath?
options: Because it is the stumblingblock of their iniquity
Because the temple treasures are hidden
Because the idols have consumed them
Because the priests have stolen it
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is the stumblingblock of their iniquity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 explains that silver and gold will not save them because they represent the stumblingblock of their iniquity, highlighting the futility of wealth in judgment.

questions.question: What does the imagery of 'doves of the valleys' in Ezekiel 7:16 most likely symbolize?
options: The scattered survivors mourning their iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: The scattered survivors mourning their iniquity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:16 uses the simile of doves on the mountains to portray those who escape as scattered and mourning, emphasizing their sorrow over sin.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated phrase 'mine eye shall not spare, neither will I have pity' in Ezekiel 7?
options: It emphasizes the severity and impartiality of God's judgment
It shows God's mercy towards Israel
It refers to the priests’ intercession
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the severity and impartiality of God's judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 9 both assert that God’s eye will not spare nor pity, underscoring the inevitability and justice of judgment against sin.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 7:26, what two conditions are said to come upon the people, leading to the loss of law and counsel?
options: Mischief upon mischief, and rumour upon rumour
Fire upon fire, and flood upon flood
Darkness upon darkness, and silence upon silence
Peace upon peace, and joy upon joy
questions.correctAnswer: Mischief upon mischief, and rumour upon rumour
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:26 describes layers of mischief and rumor leading to the collapse of law and counsel, reflecting societal breakdown.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7 prophesies that the king and prince will mourn and be clothed with desolation.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:27 specifically states that 'The king shall mourn, and the prince shall be clothed with desolation.'

questions.question: What does God declare He will do to the land and holy places in Ezekiel 7:24?
options: Bring the worst of the heathen to possess houses and defile holy places
Restore the land and sanctify the holy places
Divide the land among the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Bring the worst of the heathen to possess houses and defile holy places
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:24 prophesies that foreigners will take possession and defile the holy places, signifying judgment and desecration.

questions.question: Which theme in Ezekiel 7 is developed across other prophetic books such as Jeremiah and Isaiah?
options: The inevitability of divine judgment due to persistent sin
questions.correctAnswer: The inevitability of divine judgment due to persistent sin
questions.explanation: Like Ezekiel 7, Jeremiah and Isaiah also emphasize judgment as a consequence of Israel’s unrepented sin, highlighting a major prophetic theme.

questions.question: What does the instruction to 'Make a chain' in Ezekiel 7:23 symbolize in the context of the chapter?
options: Captivity and restraint due to blood crimes
A call to unity among the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Captivity and restraint due to blood crimes
questions.explanation: The command to 'Make a chain' in Ezekiel 7:23 symbolizes the impending captivity and punishment caused by the land’s violent crimes.

questions.question: What does the repeated refrain 'ye shall know that I am the LORD' in Ezekiel 7 emphasize about God's purpose in judgment?
options: To demonstrate His sovereignty and justice
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate His sovereignty and justice
questions.explanation: This refrain in verses 4 and 9 underscores that God's judgments are meant to reveal His sovereignty and righteousness to the people.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is alluded to in Ezekiel 7:18 when people gird themselves with sackcloth?
questions.correctAnswer: Mourning and repentance rituals
questions.explanation: The use of sackcloth was a common ancient Near Eastern symbol of mourning and repentance, as described in Ezekiel 7:18.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 7 describes a scenario where buyers rejoice and sellers mourn because of the coming wrath.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:12 specifically states, 'let not the buyer rejoice, nor the seller mourn: for wrath is upon all the multitude thereof,' indicating neither rejoices nor mourns.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Ezekiel 7 for God's judgment upon the land of Israel?
options: Because of their abominations and wickedness
Because they failed to build the temple
Because they worshiped foreign gods only
Because they refused to offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their abominations and wickedness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:3-4 states that God will judge Israel according to their ways and recompense them for their abominations. This judgment is due to their persistent sinfulness. This theme of judgment for sin aligns with Leviticus 18:30, Romans 1:18, Isaiah 13:11, and Hebrews 10:26.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7, what will God’s eye do in His judgment upon Israel?
options: Not spare and show no pity
Ignore their sins for a time
Give them a chance to repent
questions.correctAnswer: Not spare and show no pity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:4 and 7:9 declare that God's eye shall not spare, and He will not have pity, emphasizing the certainty and severity of His judgment. This reflects God's holiness and righteousness in punishing sin, as also seen in Nahum 1:3, Hebrews 10:31, Romans 2:5, and Psalm 7:11.

questions.question: What phrase does Ezekiel 7 use repeatedly to describe the imminence of God's judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: The end is come
questions.explanation: The phrase 'the end is come' appears in verses 2, 3, 5, and 6, emphasizing the finality and imminence of God's judgment. This echoes eschatological themes found in Daniel 12:1, Revelation 1:7, Joel 2:31, and 2 Timothy 4:1 regarding the coming day of the Lord.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7:15 say will happen to those who are in the city during the judgment?
options: Famine and pestilence shall devour them
They shall be protected by the Lord
They shall escape to the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Famine and pestilence shall devour them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:15 clearly states that those in the city will suffer famine and pestilence, indicating internal destruction. This reflects God's judgment through natural calamities as also described in Deuteronomy 28:21-22, Revelation 6:8, Isaiah 24:6, and Luke 21:11.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 7, what will people do with their silver and gold during the day of the Lord’s wrath?
options: Cast them into the streets because they cannot save
Use them to buy their freedom
Offer them as sacrifices to God
questions.correctAnswer: Cast them into the streets because they cannot save
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 describes people casting their silver and gold into the streets, showing that wealth cannot deliver them from God's judgment. Similar teaching is found in Habakkuk 2:8, Isaiah 30:6, Luke 12:15, and 1 Timothy 6:10 concerning the futility of riches for salvation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'rod' mentioned in Ezekiel 7:10 and 7:11?
options: A symbol of violence and wickedness rising against Israel
A sign of peace and restoration
A tool for building the temple
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of violence and wickedness rising against Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:10-11 reveals the 'rod' as blossoming and pride budding, representing violence and wickedness that will punish Israel. This symbolism of judgment through a rod or staff appears in Psalm 2:9, Isaiah 10:5, Revelation 2:27, and Hebrews 1:8 where the rod represents divine authority and judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7:18 describe as covering the people during the day of judgment?
options: Horror and shame upon all faces
questions.correctAnswer: Horror and shame upon all faces
questions.explanation: Verse 18 describes horror covering the people and shame upon all faces, indicating deep remorse and fear in judgment. This is consistent with Revelation 6:15-17, Joel 2:1-2, Isaiah 64:10, and Hebrews 12:29 describing the terror of God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 7, what will happen to the holy places of Israel during the judgment?
options: They shall be defiled and possessed by foreigners
They will be preserved and honored
They will be rebuilt by the exiles
They will be hidden from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be defiled and possessed by foreigners
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:21-24 foretells that the holy places will be given to strangers and defiled, reflecting the loss of sanctity due to Israel’s sins. This is echoed in 2 Kings 25:17, Jeremiah 7:30-34, Daniel 8:11, and Matthew 24:15 concerning the desecration of the temple.

questions.question: What is the nature of the 'evil' that has come upon the land according to Ezekiel 7:5?
options: An only evil, a unique and severe judgment
A minor punishment for a short time
A call to repentance with mercy
questions.correctAnswer: An only evil, a unique and severe judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:5 describes the evil as 'an only evil,' indicating it is a singular, unprecedented judgment. This severe divine judgment aligns with the 'day of wrath' in Romans 2:5, the 'day of the Lord' in Zephaniah 1:15, Isaiah 13:6, and Revelation 6:17.

questions.question: How are those who escape the judgments described in Ezekiel 7:16?
options: Like doves on the mountains, mourning for their iniquity
Gathering in the city with joy
questions.correctAnswer: Like doves on the mountains, mourning for their iniquity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:16 compares the survivors to doves on mountains, all mourning their sinfulness. This imagery of lamentation and sorrow in judgment is paralleled in Jeremiah 48:28, Psalm 102:6, Matthew 2:18, and Revelation 14:11 emphasizing repentance and sorrow.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7:26 say will happen to the law and counsel during this time of judgment?
options: The law shall perish from the priest, and counsel from the ancients
The law will be magnified and obeyed
Counsel will come only from prophets
The priests will enforce the law strictly
questions.correctAnswer: The law shall perish from the priest, and counsel from the ancients
questions.explanation: Verse 26 predicts the breakdown of religious and social leadership, where law and counsel fail. This loss of guidance during judgment is also seen in Hosea 4:6, Matthew 23:38, Jeremiah 2:8, and Romans 1:28 showing the consequences of rejecting divine authority.

questions.question: What is the overall theological theme of God's character revealed in Ezekiel 7?
options: God’s justice and righteous wrath against sin
God’s unconditional acceptance regardless of sin
God’s preference for ritual over righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice and righteous wrath against sin
questions.explanation: The chapter repeatedly emphasizes God's anger, judgment, and recompense for Israel’s abominations (Ezekiel 7:3-9, 23, 27). This highlights God’s holy justice consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, Romans 1:18-20, Psalm 89:14, and Revelation 19:11.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 7 illustrate the failure of wealth and human resources in the face of God's judgment?
options: Silver and gold will not deliver nor satisfy during wrath
They will buy protection from judgment
They will be used to bribe officials
They will be hidden and preserved
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold will not deliver nor satisfy during wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 7:19 states that silver and gold cannot save people in the day of the Lord’s wrath, pointing to the futility of trusting in riches. This truth is echoed in Proverbs 11:4, Isaiah 55:2, Matthew 6:19-21, and 1 Timothy 6:17-19.

questions.question: What eschatological motif is present in the repeated phrase 'the morning is come' in Ezekiel 7?
options: The arrival of the decisive day of judgment
The start of a new covenant
The birth of a messianic king
The call to worship in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The arrival of the decisive day of judgment
questions.explanation: 'The morning is come' (Ezekiel 7:7, 10) symbolizes the dawning of the day of wrath, a motif also found in Joel 2:1, Malachi 4:2, Revelation 6:12, and 2 Peter 3:10 describing the eschatological day when God executes judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 7:23 command to be made because of the land's condition?
options: Make a chain, because the land is full of bloody crimes
Build an altar for peace offerings
Prepare a feast for the Lord
Draw water for the cleansing of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Make a chain, because the land is full of bloody crimes
questions.explanation: Verse 23 calls for making a chain as a symbol of captivity or restraint due to the land's violence and bloodshed. This imagery of bondage due to sin is also in Jeremiah 38:6, Isaiah 42:7, Lamentations 3:7, and Revelation 20:1-3.
